cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic stainless steels are characterized by an austenitic metallurgical structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels including Types 304, 304L, 304H, 309, 310, 316, 316L, 316H, 321, 321H, 347, and 347H

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steels have an austenitic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.
Duplex stainless steels have a ferritic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.
Welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) structure, linking them conceptually to duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in welds of 300 Series stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MicrostructureContext: weld metal/heat-affected zone duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that welds of austenitic stainless steels can show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure; semantic mapping to the duplex stainless steel family is approximate.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are categorized based on having an austenitic metallurgical structure at room temperature.
Stainless steels are categorized based on having a ferritic metallurgical structure at room temperature.
Stainless steels are categorized based on having a martensitic metallurgical structure at room temperature.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject alloy or steel class possesses the specified metallurgical or microstructural phase/structure under the given conditions (e.g., temperature, location, or processing state).
args.justification: All six relations describe a structural/microstructural phase present in a steel or alloy (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic components, including mixed duplex structures). The existing relation_name is already a good canonical predicate, so it is reused. They clearly form a single predicate family describing which metallurgical structure a material has, which fits a structure-oriented relation class grouped under broad compositional/structural characterization.
args.remark: This canonical predicate can be reused for any material-to-metallurgical-structure linkage, with qualifiers capturing temperature (e.g., room temperature) and context (weld metal, mixed duplex, etc.).

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject material is microstructurally related to the object material, typically because it can exhibit a similar type of phase mixture or metallurgical structure under certain conditions.
args.justification: This relation does not state that austenitic stainless steels are duplex stainless steels, but that their welds may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic–ferritic) microstructure similar to duplex stainless steels. This is a looser structural association rather than direct structure possession or identity. A more specific canonical predicate 'microstructurally_related_to' captures this nuance better than a generic 'associated_with', while remaining consistent with the structural/microstructural context.
args.remark: Kept the original raw relation_name 'associated_with' as evidence but tightened the canonical predicate to reflect microstructural similarity and conditionality indicated by qualifiers (welds, may, duplex structure).
